prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Maya Fey
Description: My assistant and a disciple in the Kurain Tradition of spirit channeling.
Character 1
Name: Mia Fey
Description: Maya's older sister and my eternal mentor in life and law. Passed away 2 years ago.
Character 2
Name: Godot
Description: A prosecutor who is shrouded in mystery. He seems to know me somehow.
Character 3
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective at the local precinct. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 4
Name: Maggey Byrde
Description: A waitress at Trés Bien. Was found guilty of murder thanks to the phony me.
Character 5
Name: Jean Armstrong
Description: Trés Bien's owner and chef. A witness in the case who is also into aromatherapy.
Character 6
Name: Glen Elg
Description: The victim. Was a programmer. Maggey had apparently never even seen him before.
Character 7
Name: Victor Kudo
Description: Was in Trés Bien at the time of the incident. Has a thing for waitresses.
Character 8
Name: Lisa Basil
Description: The CEO of Blue Screens, Inc., and Glen Elg's boss. Absolutely not a robot.
Character 9
Name: Violetta → Viola Cadaverini
Description: Possibly part of the staff at Tender Lender? A thoroughly bitter person.
Character 10
Name: Furio Tigre
Description: The head of Tender Lender loan company. Also known as "The Tiger".
Character 11
Name: Bruto Cadaverini
Description: The head of the Cadaverini Family crime syndicate. Seems to live for his granddaughter.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: It's my all-important badge. It shows that I am a defense attorney.
Evidence 1
Name: Maya's Magatama
Description: A present from Maya. It reacts to people who have secrets in their hearts. On loan from Maya. Recovered in the kitchen of Trés Bien.
Evidence 2
Name: Magazine Clipping
Description: An article from December 5th. Says I was trounced and my client was found guilty.
Evidence 3
Name: Sports Paper
Description: Dates from December 3rd, the day of the incident. On it is a doodle that said 'MC Bomber' with an arrow pointing to '100,000' that was crossed out. 'Ahahahaha' and a laughing face are written next to it. Left by a costumer in Trés Bien on Dec. 3rd. Click here for details. Left by the victim. Doodle is in victim's handwriting. Click here for details.
Evidence 4
Name: Job Listings
Description: Picked up from a bench in Vitamin Square. Thrown away by the old man.
Evidence 5
Name: Lunch Special
Description: Trés Bien lunch special. Costs 20 dollars despite how unbelievably bad it tastes.
Evidence 6
Name: Small Bottle
Description: Found in the kitchen. Shape is different from the others bottles. Contents unknown. The victim's ear medicine. Found covered in unidentified fingerprints in the kitchen. The victim's ear medicine. Covered in Furio Tigre's fingerprints.
Evidence 7
Name: Scooter
Description: Ridden by my phony. The wheel guard is all smashed up.
Evidence 8
Name: Jean's Loan Contract
Description: Jean's debt is half a million dollars. The owner of the loan is Tender Lender.
Evidence 9
Name: Victor's Note
Description: "Convicted before, a wicked man or woman, repeat offender -- Victor Kudo"
Evidence 10
Name: Glen's Autopsy Report
Description: Died of potassium cyanide poisoning. Time of death was between 1:30 and 2:30 PM.
Evidence 11
Name: Trés Bien Floor Plans
Description: Blueprints of the crime scene. Click here for details. X = victim's seat.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Photo
Description: A photo of the scene taken from near the kitchen. Two dining tables are separated by a folding screen. The one closer to the camera is empty. The other one is where the victim collapse on the table. There is an intact vase on each table. A coffee cup is knocked over and the the table cloth is stained by coffee. Near the coffee table are some pieces of papers. No one is sitting across from the victim.
Evidence 13
Name: Coffee Cup
Description: The coffee contained potassium cyanide. Covered in the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right.
Evidence 14
Name: Victim's Lottery Ticket
Description: A winning ticket for half a million dollars. Found during a body search of Maggey.
Evidence 15
Name: Apron
Description: Worn by Maggey at the time of the incident. Has small pockets but big stains.
Evidence 16
Name: Potassium Cyanide
Description: A deadly powdery poison. Bears Maggey's fingerprints. Found in her apron pocket.
Evidence 17
Name: Victim's Prescription Bag
Description: The victim got this from the doctor before going to Trés Bien. The bag is empty.
There was a prescription bag on the victim's table along with the lottery ticket.
Evidence 18
Name: Victor's Testimony
Description: "When the incident occurred, I broke the vase at my seat. I'm sorry."
Evidence 19
Name: Millionaire Radio Flyer
Description: Experience the most thrilling ten minutes of your life every Monday at 1:30 PM!
Evidence 20
Name: Glen's Calendar
Description: On Dec. 3rd, the day of the incident, there is a note saying, "Meet with The Tiger".
Evidence 21
Name: Losing Horse Racing Tickets
Description: Horse racing betting tickets. Found in Glen Elg's desk. There's over 500 of them!
Evidence 22
Name: Gumshoe's Lunchbox
Description: A tenderly handmade lunchbox. Fills the stomach with love and plenty of weenies.
Evidence 23
Name: MC Bomber
Description: Found at Tender Lender. A sample disc with the name written in marker. Found at Tender Lender. Contains a computer virus program. A computer virus made by Glen Elg. Potentially worth million of dollars.
Evidence 24
Name: Trés Bien Matches
Description: Matches used for advertising. Found lying in Tender Lender.
Evidence 25
Name: Repair Bill
Description: A car repair bill for $15,000. Paid by Tigre to the Cadaverini Family.
Evidence 26
Name: Paper Badge
Description: Found at Tender Lender. Made of cardboard and painted to look authentic.
Evidence 27
Name: Viola's Medical Papers
Description: A 1 million dollar bill for cranial surgery. Payment was due last year.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The crime was reported at 2:25 PM by a kind of scary old man, sir.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 1
Testimony: Poor Maggey had passed out from the shock. It must've been real tough for her.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 2
Testimony: The victim didn't have any identification on him.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 3
Testimony: But we figured out who he was pretty quick, and then the investigation went smoothly.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 4
Testimony: When Maggey was searched, we found the lottery ticket and the bottle of poison.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 5
Testimony: And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene.
Person: Gumshoe

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
response:
Upon carefully examining the evidence and testimonies, we notice a critical contradiction. In Testimony 5, Detective Gumshoe states, "And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene." However, this contradicts Evidence 17, the Victim's Prescription Bag, which notes, "There was a prescription bag on the victim's table along with the lottery ticket." Yet, later information in the evidence shows that this bag is mentioned but not found as part of the investigation report by Gumshoe. This indicates a contradiction regarding whether all items present were accounted for.

{"evidence": 17, "testimony": 5}

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The young man was reading the sports paper.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 1
Testimony: The serving girl brought him a javaccino... But she put something in it!
Person: Kudo
Testimony 2
Testimony: There's no question about it! She very conspicuously put some white powder in there.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 3
Testimony: The man took one sip of it, looked like he was in terrible pain, and then collapsed.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 4
Testimony: That's the serving girl, right there in the defendant's chair. I remember her well!
Person: Kudo
Testimony 5
Testimony: There was a ribbon in her hair, and her apron's straps were loose.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 6
Testimony: There wasn't anything that caught my interest about her when I saw her from the front.
Person: Kudo

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
response:
To solve this problem, we need to identify an evidence that contradicts a part of the testimony. We can see that Testimony 0 to Testimony 5 come from Kudo, and he claims that Maggey Byrde, the defendant, put white powder in the coffee which he believes led to the victim’s collapse (Testimony 1 and Testimony 2). This might suggest poisoning by potassium cyanide.

The contradiction can be seen between Victor Kudo’s Testimony 2 and the physical evidence at the scene. Kudo states that he saw Maggey put white powder into the javaccino, but importantly, Examining Evidence 13 (the Coffee Cup) shows both the victim and Maggey's fingerprints, but it was noted that the victim took one sip of it, looked in terrible pain, and then collapsed (Testimony 3). However, Kudo’s claim is questionable as no other detailed evidence supports the sight of powder being added to the drink or any strong evidence confirming Maggey's visibility with respect to the coffee cup in the testimony. 

A closer look shows, according to Evidence 19, that the 'Millionaire Radio Flyer' provides an alibi, indicating that the victim's distraction for ten minutes aligns with the program's timing at 1:30 PM. Coupled with the evidence of handwritten notes and the intuition that the timeline doesn’t pin the collapse accurately, there's potential for other manipulation unseen by Kudo at that event.

So contrasting Testimony 3, where the sequence is collapse after one sip, may be interesting, but ultimately what strikes me most likely as suspect in this testimony is his visual account of the poisoning when the actual death sequence might suggest him already being distracted so failing to visually confirm the alleged sodium cyanide event at 1:30 — the Radio program's precise schedule, aligning fishily with victim's last moments, distinct from Kudo's white powder interpretation.

Thus, linking the more circumstantial, the timeline of victim's poisoning resting on Kudo's white powder tale diverges, but doesn’t quite hit in direct collision yet if analyzed further grains might rearrange fitting assumptions for a different structured grudge killing narrative; nonetheless holding answer strictly enclosed limits unless narrative ties in presenting foreseen brewed conjecture.

{"evidence": 12, "testimony": 3}

Testimony 0
Testimony: He was another of those pesky young types, wearing a broken pair of spectacles.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 1
Testimony: He had a newspaper in his right hand, and the noisy brat kept rustling its pages!
Person: Kudo
Testimony 2
Testimony: The young man was listening to the wireless. I remember that well.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 3
Testimony: Then the serving girl in question brought over the javaccino.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 4
Testimony: The little fidget picked up the cup with his free hand and took a sip.
Person: Kudo

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
response:
To find a contradiction between evidence and testimony, we need to match the details.

Testimony 3 says: "Then the serving girl in question brought over the javaccino."

This testimony from Victor Kudo implies that Maggey Byrde, the waitress, served the coffee (javaccino) to the victim, Glen Elg. However, there's evidence that suggests otherwise.

Evidence 13, the Coffee Cup, states: "The coffee contained potassium cyanide. Covered in the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right. He had a newspaper in his right hand."

This evidence suggests that Maggey Byrde's fingerprints were on the cup, which could be consistent with her serving it, but there's a detail that needs to be considered further. Testimony 2 from Victor Kudo mentions the victim was listening to the wireless, which implies he wouldn't be able to easily take the cup and drink with his other hand, yet according to Testimony 4, he picked it up with his free hand. 

However, the contradiction is more apparent when looking at the circumstances of Maggey being accused. Instead, here's the more significant contradiction:

Testimony 1: "He had a newspaper in his right hand, and the noisy brat kept rustling its pages!" 
This implies the victim's right hand was occupied with the newspaper.

Comparing this with the detail from Evidence 13:
"He had a newspaper in his right hand." 

There's a direct match in details, emphasizing that the victim could not have picked up the coffee with the right hand as stated in Testimony 4: "The little fidget picked up the cup with his free hand and took a sip." This implies a problem because the use of a free hand contradicts the claim that both drinks were picked with the free hands while holding multiple items.

However, for a direct evidence-testimony contradiction, linking back, if we look one more time at Testimony 3 and the details about Maggey being found guilty because of a "phony me," it becomes evident that the contradiction comes more directly because the implication is that Maggey herself did not actually apply the poison or directly serve the cup poisoned.

Thus, a more straightforward contradiction for Testimony 3 may come from examining the nature of how the javaccino was served (i.e., by potential phony representation as evidence does not directly on that).

In any case, let's focus directly on finding a form of contradiction that states, rather directly, that the evidence shows concerning the testimonies the possible contradictions such as through a direct claim associated (such as through scheduling or different addressing if further given evidence).

Ultimately, the particular direct contradiction we're pointing, the answer in a simple manner:

{"evidence": 12, "testimony": 1}

Near the coffee table are some pieces of papers. No one is sitting across from the victim.
Evidence 13
Name: Coffee Cup
Description: The coffee contained potassium cyanide. Covered in the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right.
Evidence 14
Name: Victim's Lottery Ticket
Description: A winning ticket for half a million dollars. Found during a body search of Maggey.
Evidence 15
Name: Apron
Description: Worn by Maggey at the time of the incident. Has small pockets but big stains.
Evidence 16
Name: Potassium Cyanide
Description: A deadly powdery poison. Bears Maggey's fingerprints. Found in her apron pocket.
Evidence 17
Name: Victim's Prescription Bag
Description: The victim got this from the doctor before going to Trés Bien. The bag is empty.
Evidence 18
Name: Victor's Testimony
Description: "When the incident occurred, I broke the vase at my seat. I'm sorry."
Evidence 19
Name: Millionaire Radio Flyer
Description: Experience the most thrilling ten minutes of your life every Monday at 1:30 PM!
Evidence 20
Name: Glen's Calendar
Description: On Dec. 3rd, the day of the incident, there is a note saying, "Meet with The Tiger".
Evidence 21
Name: Losing Horse Racing Tickets
Description: Horse racing betting tickets. Found in Glen Elg's desk. There's over 500 of them!
Evidence 22
Name: Gumshoe's Lunchbox
Description: A tenderly handmade lunchbox. Fills the stomach with love and plenty of weenies.
Evidence 23
Name: MC Bomber
Description: Found at Tender Lender. A sample disc with the name written in marker. Found at Tender Lender. Contains a computer virus program. A computer virus made by Glen Elg. Potentially worth million of dollars.
Evidence 24
Name: Trés Bien Matches
Description: Matches used for advertising. Found lying in Tender Lender.
Evidence 25
Name: Repair Bill
Description: A car repair bill for $15,000. Paid by Tigre to the Cadaverini Family.
Evidence 26
Name: Paper Badge
Description: Found at Tender Lender. Made of cardboard and painted to look authentic.
Evidence 27
Name: Viola's Medical Papers
Description: A 1 million dollar bill for cranial surgery. Payment was due last year.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: First of all, I want to stress that this might be nothing. I'm not too sure of myself.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 1
Testimony: The young boy slumped over the table as soon as he took one sip of his javaccino...
Person: Kudo
Testimony 2
Testimony: Well, the clumsy idiot upset the vase. He knocked it right over.
Person: Kudo
Testimony 3
Testimony: It broke, and the strip of cloth covering the table got completely soaked!
Person: Kudo
Testimony 4
Testimony: Well!? How about that? Turned things upside-down, hmm?
Person: Kudo

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
response:
The contradiction lies between the evidence of the Crime Photo and Victor Kudo's testimony. The Crime Photo (Evidence 12) describes a scene with an intact vase on each table, and one of the tables having a coffee stain, but not the other. In contrast, Kudo's Testimony 3 indicates that a vase was knocked over, and the tablecloth got completely soaked, implying a mess that is not apparent in the Crime Photo. 

{"evidence": 12, "testimony": 3}
